Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Transcranial Dynamic Focused Ultrasound for the Non-Invasive Opening of the Blood-Brain Barrier (BBB)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project aims to develop technology designed to provide physicians with a new capability to manage patients with brain diseases such as brain cancers, Alzheimer’s or Parkinson’s. One reason brain disease is difficult to treat is the existence of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) that prevents almost all therapeutic agents from reaching diseased tissue from blood. The proposed technology enables opening the BBB in a non-invasive manner with a system that is portable and may be deployed in an out-patient or a clinic setting. This system could impact the cost burden of managing patients with brain diseases and provide better quality of life.

The proposed project develops methods to accurately direct focused beams of ultrasound to therapy targets within the patient’s brain from an array of ultrasound transducers embedded in a cap-like device conformed comfortably to a patient’s head. In the last several years, focused ultrasound with microbubbles (an FDA approved ultrasound contrast agent) has been used to transiently open the BBB to administer drugs or provide therapy. The proposed cap-like device includes mechanisms both to conform to the patient head and to measure the resulting alignment to the patient anatomy. The envisioned method is to acquire information on cap placement and MR and CT images of the specific patient
in advance so that the therapeutic ultrasound can then be directed accurately to targets within the patient's brain. The proposed work includes a) developing beamforming algorithms applicable to a range of patient head sizes, with transducer elements arranged on the conforming cap; and (b) understanding and mitigating potential sources of errors limiting the performance. The project will conduct simulation and analysis using MR and CT images from real patients, obtained from the U.S. National Library of Medicine Visible Human Project, resulting in specifications suitable for construction of a laboratory device for verification and validation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Brain diseases impose a staggering cost on society. According to a 2016 report from the Information Technology & Innovation Foundation, mental and neurological diseases and disorders cost the US economy more than $1.5 trillion per year. According to another report published by the Family Caregiver Alliance, more than one million adults in the U.S are diagnosed annually with a chronic brain disease or disorder. Given the aging of the population in the U.S., these numbers are expected to grow. There is thus a significant unmet need to address these issues. Brain diseases such as brain cancer, Parkinson’s, Alzheimer’s are hard to treat partly due to the anatomy of the brain. The blood-brain barrier, which is an anatomical structure in the brain, prevents the passage of almost all known therapeutic agents (such as chemotherapies) from the blood into the brain tissue. The blood-brain barrier is an integral part of the walls of the vessels that transport blood in the brain. Focused ultrasound is a technology that can create a temporary passageway through the blood-brain barrier and enable therapeutic agents to pass from the blood into the tissue. Cordance Medical is developing a non-invasive, portable, cost-effective, focused ultrasound-based device to enable the targeted opening of the blood-brain barrier. In the Phase 1 SBIR project, Cordance Medical developed techniques to guide ultrasound energy accurately to various parts of the brain. Our study indicates that our techniques can be applied broadly across a range of patients and can accommodate patient-to-patient variations stemming from the differences in the physical and acoustic properties of the tissues of the head.  Further, we demonstrated that our technique has the potential of meeting success criteria as defined by the clinical requirements.  One key output of the Phase 1 project is a set of software-based tools that can simulate the propagation of sound in layered media such as exists in skull bone and brain tissue. This toolset will be extremely useful during the design and development of our system.

 

Our techniques can be applied broadly across various diseases and can thus have a broad positive impact on patients with brain diseases. In some diseases such as brain cancer, the opportunity to apply our technique is more immediate as drugs that can potentially provide therapeutic benefits already exist but cannot be effectively delivered. Besides providing a therapeutic benefit, our system can also be used for drug discovery and development.
